header.title: The Scroll of Set - October 1997
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setian Philosophy, Left-Hand Path

central_thesis: The collection explores various facets of Setian philosophy, magical practice, and the identity of the Temple of Set. Key themes include the nature of initiation (Xeper), the distinction and relationship with other occult orders (A.'.A.'., O.T.O.), the Setian interpretation of morality and spirituality (Left-Hand Path, Black Flame), and practical applications in personal transformation and martial arts. It emphasizes self-deification, individual will, and the active creation of one's reality.

structure_content.chapter_title: It's the A.'.A.'., Not the O.Τ.Ο.
structure_content.summary: This article differentiates the Order of Horus (a Setian initiatory order focused on Xeper and a Remanifestation of the A.'.A.'. in a Left-Hand Path context) from the O.T.O., highlighting shared A.'.A.'. roots but distinct aims and methodologies.

This section lists recent recognitions of members to various degrees within the Temple of Set, including Magister Templi IV° and Priesthood of Set III°, noting the names of the individuals and the Magister(s) who recognized them.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Fall in Theory and Practice: Arioch Speaks
structure_content.summary: This article presents a mythical/allegorical account of the 'Fall' from grace, reframing it as a conscious choice for evolution, individuality, and strength in darkness, contrasting with stagnancy and externally imposed order.

An allegorical narrative describing an invocation of Satan, discussing the desire for a 'Satanic Order' within the Temple of Set, and exploring classical Satanism from a unique Setian perspective, distinct from common misinterpretations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Pharaonic Thinking: Keys to an Enigma
structure_content.summary: This article explores R.A. Schwaller de Lubicz's concept of 'pharaonic thinking' as a methodology for understanding reality through vital principles, resonance, and Hermetic extension/retraction, emphasizing its applicability to Setian Xeper and self-deification.

This report covers the Munich Conclave, emphasizing the international expansion of the Temple of Set, significant member recognitions, and the workings of various orders. It also discusses the Pergamon Altar as 'the Seat of Satan' and its relevance to Setian philosophy of self-deification.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Great Pyramid of Kohlberg: The Morality of the Setian Mind
structure_content.summary: This article adapts Kohlberg's stages of moral development by proposing a seventh, 'Setian' level, focusing on the non-natural mind, individual principles, and transcending profane self-awareness to achieve a higher moral autonomy.
A brief announcement of the engagement of Priest James L. Knowles, Jr. and Adept Debra A. Hoffman, noting their planned Setian ceremony.

A review section covering music (Steve Roach, Michael Stearns, Ron Sunsinger, Kiva; Knot in the Loop, Above Treeline by Heather Keller) and film (L'Avventura by Michelangelo Antonioni), analyzed from a Setian/occult perspective.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Word of Set in our Initiatory and Evolutionary Life
structure_content.summary: This article reflects on the 'Nineteen Parts of the Word' and 'orderings of being,' discussing the evolutionary potential of the human race and the importance of preserving the Temple of Set as a living body of Initiates to achieve essential life and Xeper.

structure_content.chapter_title: Recognizing the Black Flame Among the Herd
structure_content.summary: This article discusses the concept of the 'Black Flame' as inherent individuality and potential for awakening, distinguishing 'Children of Night' from 'Children of Day' based on their perception of the Dark. It offers guidance for identifying potential Setians in the wider world.
A brief review and advertisement for a CD release by Black Magical Death Rock band 'Morphine Angel' called 'LoveNest & MurderFest', highlighting its themes and guest appearances.

This article defines antinomianism as spiritual dissent from externally imposed moral law, asserting that morality should issue from the individual's soul. It distinguishes the Left-Hand Path (self-deification) from the Right-Hand Path (merging with God) based on fundamental intention.

This article explores the Celtic triscele symbol and its connection to a threefold universe and the color wheel, suggesting its application to understanding polarity and the intermediate realms of existence within a magical context.

This article describes a ritual aimed at self-creation and empowerment by embracing inherent beauty and strength, using goddesses as symbols and focusing on inner transformation through will and the Black Flame.
An excerpt of a poem by Lord Byron, presenting a Gothic/Romantic vision of a vampire's curse and its enduring impact.

structure_content.chapter_title: Things Not to Put on Envelopes to Setians
structure_content.summary: A humorous and practical guide listing examples of inappropriate or overly occult-themed content for mail sent to Setians, emphasizing discretion and avoiding common clichés.

structure_content.chapter_title: Media-Mongering: How Heaven's Gate was turned into Hell's Gate
structure_content.summary: A critical analysis of media's portrayal of the Heaven's Gate mass suicide, contrasting 'objective journalism' with sensationalism, and urging Setians to actively counter misconceptions about Satanism and the Left-Hand Path.

A practical guide for authors submitting articles electronically to The Scroll, offering technical advice on file formats, attachments, and formatting to ensure submissions are received and processed correctly by editors.
Announcements for upcoming Southeastern and Southwestern Regional Conclaves, including dates and contact information for interested members.

This article discusses the history of the Temple of Set, particularly focusing on the 'Xem' current associated with Ronald K. Barrett, and its impact on the Order of Anpu and the ongoing exploration of Setian philosophy and legacy.

This article explores the concept of a magical name as a Setian nickname or identity, reflecting an individual's chosen path and aspiration, and suggesting its use for self-reflection and understanding one's initiation journey and personal divinity.

structure_content.chapter_title: Xem-Set: The Process of Creating a Setian Martial Arts Tradition
structure_content.summary: This article proposes the creation of a Setian martial arts tradition ('Sethenu-Tep' Guild) rooted in ancient Egyptian warrior-priest traditions, emphasizing martial arts as a path for Xeper, energy manipulation, and the manifestation of divine will and essence of being.

key_concepts.definition: To become; the core Setian process of self-creation, transformation, and individual awakening, aiming for self-deification and the manifestation of divine will.
The innate divine essence, individuality, and potential for self-deification within each Setian, which is to be awakened and nurtured.

A spiritual path characterized by the intention of self-deification and separation from external divine forces, emphasizing individual will, self-responsibility, and the active creation of one's reality.
A spiritual path characterized by the intention of merging with God or nature, allowing external doctrines to define self-responsibility and often leading to dissolution of individual self.

Spiritual dissent from externally imposed religious, cultural, or social moral laws, advocating for morality to issue from the individual's soul, heart, and conscience through personal experience and philosophical inquiry.

A method of understanding reality, as described by R.A. Schwaller de Lubicz, through vital principles, resonance, and Hermetic extension/retraction, connecting the phenomenal world to an internal spiritual reality base.

A chosen name in a magical setting that reflects an individual's aspirations, path, and identity as a magical being, used for self-reflection, understanding one's initiation journey, and manifesting one's true will.

An initiatory order within the Temple of Set, described as a Remanifestation of the A.'.A.'. reorganized along Left-Hand Path lines, focused on working with the neter Horus, self-deification, and applying principles used by Setian pharaohs.

A proposed Setian martial arts tradition combining martial arts with Xeper, energy manipulation, and the manifestation of divine will, drawing from ancient Egyptian warrior-priest traditions and martial philosophies.
The proposed guild for Setian martial artists, named after a group of ancient Egyptian warrior god-kings from Southern Egypt, dedicated to the Black Art of martial combat as a path for Xeper.

One of Aleister Crowley's distinct magical organizations, focused on initiation and self-transformation, whose principles are reinterpreted and remanifested by the Order of Horus in a Left-Hand Path context.

A Masonic-based magical organization influenced and reshaped by Aleister Crowley, distinct from the Order of Horus despite shared A.'.A.'. lineage, serving as a vehicle for the manifestation of Thelema.

practical_system.description: The core practical system is centered around Xeper, individual will, and the manifestation of the Black Flame. It involves a continuous process of self-creation, transformation, and active engagement with one's subjective and objective realities. This is achieved through various methodologies including philosophical inquiry (e.g., pharaonic thinking, antinomianism), ceremonial magic, self-observation, martial arts, and the strategic identification of potential Setians in the wider world. The emphasis is on internalizing principles, developing a personal moral code, and using magical practices to actualize one's divine potential.
tools: Knowledge of Crowleyan tradition, Egyptian/Hebraic/Hindu psycho-spiritual paths
Protection of Sekhmet and wisdom of Thoth (for dangerous tasks)
rituals: On Beauty and Strength ritual (invoking goddesses/gods as symbols of beauty and strength, meditating on true will and the Black Flame)
Various Conclave Workings (e.g., Order of Leviathan, Order of Merlin, I°/II° Working, Order of the Vampyre)
Proposed Xem-Set martial arts rituals/training for self-creation and energy manipulation
Invocation of Majesty of Set and Horus (for experimentation and fusion of entities)
Ritual of laying down the foundation for the Temple in Europe

relevant_quotes.text: Every man must overcome his own obstacles, expose his own illusions. Yet others may assist him to do both, and they may enable him altogether to avoid many of the false paths, leading no whither, which tempt the weary feet of the uninitiated pilgrim.

The Order of Horus is expressly a Remanifestation of the A.'.A.'. modifying and reconstituting many of the A.'.A.'.'s 'ground rules' in accordance with Left-Hand Path initiation. After all its Grand Master is an avowed Black Brother!
This 'divine transformation' is the common ground between Setian and Horian magic, and forms the basis for the Order of Horus.

The true distinction between the LHP and the RHP is one of intention: The LHP seeks a separation from God or nature for the purpose of self-deification and the inherent personal responsibilities this implies.
Only if you are known as a strictly ethical individual will your rejection of social norms be tolerated.
The mind's capacity is inexhaustible; its manifestations are unlimited.
Do What Thou Wilt shall be the whole of the Law. Great is the might of Set, greater still is he through us.

The Order of Horus has three primary features: (1) it works with the neter Horus directly, something that hasn't been done since Crowley. (2) It is a Remanifestation of the A.'.A.'., reorganized along the lines of a Left-Hand Path organization. (3) It teaches the process of self-deification, using the same principles that were used by the Setian pharaohs of ancient Egypt.
The Word of the Æon is Xeper.

If you're a Child of Night, you know the Dark to be a rich "emptiness” filled with potential. All coldness and black, yet nothing for a Night Child to fear. Night Children know that as long as they hunger for challenge and initiation, the tension provided will be food for our Xepering souls. It is home to us.

critical_analysis.relevance: The articles collectively provide a comprehensive snapshot of the Temple of Set's internal discourse in 1997, detailing its philosophical foundations, practical applications, and evolving identity. They are highly relevant for understanding the specific esoteric interpretations, history, and operational principles of the Temple of Set as a modern Left-Hand Path organization. They also demonstrate how Setianism integrates diverse magical traditions (Crowleyan, Egyptian, Celtic, martial arts) into its unique framework of self-deification (Xeper) and individual empowerment.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Primarily Initiates and members of the Temple of Set, particularly those interested in the internal workings, philosophical distinctions, and practical magic of the Order. Also highly relevant for scholars of modern esotericism and new religious movements seeking primary source insights into Setianism, its specific terminology, and the broader Left-Hand Path tradition.
